intro: Siler montanum subsp. corrasianum, commonly known as the mountain siler, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes many aromatic plants such as carrots and parsley. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in temperate climates. Its leaves are pinnately compound, and it produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels. The subspecies corrasianum is distinguished by its slightly different leaf morphology and habitat preferences compared to other subspecies of Siler montanum.
